instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2879: What is 820-2879? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: High fan, no bad sensor, no system slowdown
threads.message:
Greetings.  I have an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board with high fan.  Diagnostics showed no bad sensor and system also does not show any slow down.  All seems to work well otherwise.  All measures well around fan connector (<RESISTOR>R5660</RESISTOR>, <RESISTOR>R5661</RESISTOR>, <RESISTOR>R6556</RESISTOR>). I replaced <TRANSISTOR>Q5660</TRANSISTOR> just to cover my bases.  I replaced trackpad also but no luck.  Any thoughts on where to look next?

Paul

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: High fan, no bad sensor, no system slowdown
threads.message: Does it spin on full immediately on power up? Tried a different fan?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: High fan, no bad sensor, no system slowdown
threads.message: I tried a few different fans, checked actual temps and everything looks normal.  On power up the fan starts normal but slowly builds up speed - it takes about a minute to hit full speed.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: High fan, no bad sensor, no system slowdown
threads.message: Check all temps in the hardware profile in ASD. Slowly building up is a typical sensor issue. Maybe one of them is reading high. Also disconnect battery and see if it is ok.
